questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following ACE inhibitors is not a prodrug?
questions.explanation: Lisinopril is not a prodrug. All ACE inhibitors are prodrugs except lisinopril and captopril.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient with BP 225/145 presents with acute pulmonary edema and is diagnosed with 
hypertensive emergency. The active metabolite of which ACE inhibitor is available for 
intravenous use in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Enalapril is available in its active form as enalaprilat for intravenous use. Enalapril is a prodrug of enalaprilat. It is indicated in conditions where oral drugs cannot be used 
or rapid onset of action is desired like in a case of hypertensive emergency.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements regarding ACE inhibitors is true?

options.a: They inhibit the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I
options.b: Omission of prior diuretic dose decreases the risk of postural hypotension
options.c: Lisinopril is shorter acting than enalapril
options.d: They are contraindicated in diabetic patients

questions.explanation:
The omission of prior diuretic dose decreases the risk of postural hypotension. ACE inhibitors cause arteriolar dilation and increase the compliance of larger arteries. ACE 
inhibitors induced hypotension is thereby due to a decrease in total peripheral resistance. In 
diuretic-treated patients, the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system is more active to compensate 
for volume loss. Hence, ACE inhibitors increase the risk of postural hypotension in these 
patients. Option A: ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II. Option C: Lisinopril is longer acting than enalapril. Lisinopril is usually administered once daily in 
all patients. Enalapril requires twice-daily administration in some patients. Option D: ACE inhibitors and ARBs are first-line agents in diabetic patients because of their 
renoprotective effects.

questions.question: Question 4: All of the following are indications for the use of ACE inhibitors except:
questions.explanation:
ACE inhibitors are usually avoided in conditions like pheochromocytoma which is associated 
with high renin activity. Abrupt inhibition of the RAAS system can result in severe hypotension 
(usually postural). The majority of pheochromocytomas are treated surgically. Phenoxybenzamine is often used in 
preparing the patient for surgery and also to manage hypertension in inoperable or malignant 247 
Sold by @itachibot pheochromocytoma. Phentolamine can also be used in the short-term control of hypertension in 
these patients. ACE inhibitors are indicated in hypertensive emergency, myocardial infarction, and left 
ventricular dysfunction.

questions.question: Question 5: In which of the following patients are ACE inhibitors not contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
ACE inhibitors are not contraindicated in unilateral renal artery stenosis, left ventricular systolic 
dysfunction, and scleroderma renal crisis. Patient 1: ACE inhibitors are teratogenic and can cause hypoplasia of organs, renal failure, anuria, 
and growth retardation in the fetus. Therefore, they are contraindicated in pregnancy. Patient 2: ACE inhibitors can be used with caution in unilateral renal artery stenosis if the other 
kidney is functioning normally. Patient 3: Efferent arteriolar constriction maintains the glomerular filtration pressure in bilateral 
renal artery stenosis. ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in bilateral renal stenosis as they can 
precipitate acute renal failure due to dilation of efferent arterioles and fall in glomerular filtration 
pressure. Patient 4: ACE inhibition in patients with systolic dysfunction prevents or delays the progression 
of heart failure, decreases the incidence of sudden death and myocardial infarction, and improves 
the quality of life. ACE inhibition reduces afterload and systolic wall stress, and both cardiac 
output and cardiac index increase. Patient 5: The use of ACE inhibitors considerably improves the survival of patients with 
scleroderma renal crisis.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 53-year-old hypertensive patient has been on ACE inhibitors for the last 12 years. Which of 
the following effects would you expect to see in this patient?

options.a: Rightward shift in renal pressure natriuresis curve
options.d: Decrease in compliance of large arteries

questions.explanation:
ACE inhibitors, when used for a long time in patients with hypertension, cause a reduction in 
filtration fraction. Filtration fraction is the ratio of GFR to that of renal plasma flow. ACE inhibitors increase renal 
blood flow without altering GFR and thus result in reduction of filtration fraction. Option A: The graph plotted between urinary sodium excretion and mean blood pressure is 
known as the pressure natriuresis curve. For example, when dietary sodium intake is low, renin 
release is stimulated. Angiotensin II acts on the kidneys to shift the renal pressure – natriuresis 
curve to the right. This increases sodium and water retention. Conversely, when dietary Na+ is high or when ACE inhibitors are used, there is the withdrawal of 
angiotensin II. The renal pressure natriuresis curve shifts to the left. The following image depicts a pressure natriuresis curve: 248 
Sold by @itachibot Options C and D: ACE inhibitors do not cause a significant increase in heart rate and can have a 
favorable change in the compliance of large arteries on long-term use.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient who is started on lisinopril for hypertension is concerned about its adverse effects. 
Which among the following is not an adverse effect of this drug?
questions.explanation:
ACE inhibitors are associated with the development of hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia occurs due to the inhibition of angiotensin II-mediated aldosterone secretion. 
Decreased aldosterone levels result in decreased tubular excretion of potassium in the kidneys 
leading to hyperkalemia. The adverse effects of ACE inhibitors are: • Hypotension • Hyperkalemia • Cough • Angioedema • Skin rash • Teratogenicity • Dysgeusia (alteration in or loss of taste) Extremely rare but reversible side effects include neutropenia, glycosuria in the absence of 
hyperglycemia, anemia, and hepatotoxicity.

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient presents to the casualty with cough, difficulty in breathing, and non-indurating 
edema of his face and lips. He had recently been started on ramipril for hypertension. Which 
among the following mediates these adverse effects? 244 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema which occurs due to 
bradykinin. 249 
Sold by @itachibot Angioedema is most commonly mediated by histamine. However, bradykinin-mediated 
angioedema, though less common, can result due to hereditary or acquired defects in C1 esterase 
inhibitor and as a side effect of ACE inhibitors. ACE has structural similarity to another enzyme called kininase. Kininase normally metabolizes 
bradykinin, substance P, and prostaglandins. ACE inhibitors when administered also block 
kininase enzyme which results in an increase in the concentration of these substrates. An increase 
in the level of bradykinin/ substance P levels results in persistent brassy cough and angioedema in 
the patients.

questions.question:
Question 9: An 1Ž-year-old boy is brought to the casualty with complaints of swelling of his face and lips 
as shown in the image below. On further enquiry, it is noted that he has suffered from similar 
episodes in the past whenever he becomes emotional. He is prescribed icatibant. What is the 
likely mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image showing swelling of the face and lips is suggestive 
of hereditary angioedema. Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor competitive 
antagonist indicated for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema. The other drug which is approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema is 
ecallantide which is a synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor. Both these drugs are administered 
subcutaneously.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 40-year-old diabetic male is on ACE inhibitors for hypertension. Which among the 
following is the most serious adverse effect you would expect to see in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The most significant adverse effect seen with the use of ACE inhibitors is hypotension. ACE inhibitors are used in the management of hypertension and are one of the first-line drugs for 
this condition. Option B: ACE inhibitors may cause hyperkalemia in patients with renal insufficiency or diabetes. Options C and D: ACE inhibitors do not affect calcium levels significantly.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 40-year-old man is diagnosed with hypertension and is prescribed losartan. Which of the 
following statements about the drug is incorrect?

options.a: It is a competitive angiotensin receptor antagonist

questions.explanation:
Losartan use is not associated with hyperuricemia. In fact, losartan is uricosuric and can also be 
used in patients with gout. Losartan is a competitive angiotensin II receptor antagonist. It binds to the AT1 receptor with 
high affinity. it is also a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor and attenuates 
platelet aggregation. Losartan has no effect on ACE and it does not inhibit bradykinin breakdown. 
This results in negligible incidences of cough.

Question 12: Combined use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs are not routinely indicated primarily due to the 
increased risk of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
250
